Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Novel Query Processing Techniques for Distributed Probabilistic Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Data are increasingly generated, stored, and processed distributively. Meanwhile, when large amounts of data are generated, ambiguity, uncertainty, and errors are inherently introduced, especially in a distributed setup. It is best to represent such data in a distributed probabilistic database. In distributed data management, summary queries are useful tools for obtaining the most important answers from massive quantities of data effectively and efficiently, e.g., top-k queries, heavy hitters (aka frequent items), histograms and wavelets, threshold monitoring queries, etc. This project investigates novel query processing techniques for various, important summary queries in distributed probabilistic data.

Broadly classified, this project examines both snapshot summary queries in static (i.e., no updates) distributed probabilistic databases, and continuous summary queries in dynamic (i.e., with updates) distributed probabilistic databases. A number of techniques are explored to design novel, communication and computation efficient algorithms for processing these queries.

A distributed probabilistic data management system (DPDMS) prototype is implemented based on the query processing techniques developed in this project. This DPDMS is released to and used in practice by scientists and engineers from other science disciplines as well as industry.

Graduate and undergraduate students, including those from minority groups, are actively involved in this project. Findings from the project have been integrated into different courses, demos, and educational projects. For further information, such as publications, data sets, source code, and education initiatives, please visit the project website at http://www.cs.fsu.edu/~lifeifei/dpdm.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has supported the PI and a number of PhD students and undergraduate students to investigate novel query processing techniques for data with uncertainty and inaccuracy. In particular, the project focused on addressing various challenges resulted from a distributed query processing environment. Through the investigation conducted in this project, a suite of new query processing techniques have been designed and implemented; most of these techniques are now open sourced on Github or the project website. A US patent developed based on the techniques designed in this project has also been awarded. A number of publications in high impact venues have been published, and they helped disseminate the results to the communities of interest.

A particularly novel contribution made by the investigation from this project is new techniques for distributed online tracking over data from multiple, distributed sites that are potentially fuzzy and inaccurate. Novel approximation algorithms were designed to track and monitor, and report back high quality (approximate) query results without incurring significant communication and computation overhead. The proposed methods lead to significant savings compared to the naive approach of transmitting all data to a centralized location for further processing. Novel data summaries were also designed and built under the support of this project for large-scale probabilistic databases, for example, building V-opt style histograms for a large probabilistic database. 

The results produced in this project have been integrated into practical application modules such as CloudWatch. It was demonstrated that the proposed distributed online tracking methods can significantly improve the effectiveness and efficiency of tracking and monitoring cloud resource usage, which helps build a more secure and more reliable cloud infrastructure. 

Throughout the course of this project,  various education and outreach activities were organized to help make broader impacts. Results of this research have been integrated into the teaching curriculum of the PI and have contributed to the growth of the Big Data Certificate Program at the University of Utah, that trains a significant number of working professionals from nearby communities. 


Last Modified: 11/22/2017
Modified by: Feifei Li
